Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Developing healthcare service robots to improve hospital workflow
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project on health care service robots is in improving the quality of care in hospital systems that are increasingly burdened by an aging population and labor shortages. This project has potential for positive societal impact by reducing the workload of medical staff whose primary responsibilities require special training and human-centered skills, such as nurses. With U.S. life expectancy on the rise, skilled nurses are becoming more in demand. Automation could ameliorate the labor shortage by allowing humans to focus on providing skilled care. In addition, the proposed project aims for our technology to be general-purpose enough to eventually transfer to other markets, such as longterm care facilities and eventually individual consumers. Robots that perform assistive tasks in homes could increase the feasibility of independent living for many older adults.

The proposed project is aimed at establishing the technical and commercial feasibility of our approach. The team is working closely with a strategic partner hospital to first establish a process map and understand where service robots could have the most impact in their workflow, defining the highest impact robot tasks. The core technology proposed in this project will be around the learning algorithms for quickly and efficiently training the needed behaviors for robots to accomplish these high-impact tasks in a hospital setting. Additionally the team is in building social robots that work seamlessly in dynamic human environments. The ultimate goal is to develop a service robot that hospital staff view as a competent member of the care team. Finally it is proposed to pilot test the developed robot technology in a month-long trial, quantifying the impact that reduced workload can have on the nursing staff along a number of dimensions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Projects Outcomes Report

 

Project Title: SBIR Phase I: Developing healthcare service robots to improve hospital workflow 


PI: Bill Donges 


Awardee: Diligent Droids, LLC

 
Award Number: 1621651


Award Ended: 12/31/2016


Program Officer Name: Jesus Soriano Molla

 
Program Officer Email Address: jsoriano@nsf.gov


Program Officer Phone Number: (703)292-7795

Diligent Droids successfully built and demonstrated a mobile manipulation hospital service robot that is both adaptive and interactive. The company showed the technical feasibility of deploying robots in hospitals to achieve room-level stocking of patient supplies without the increased burden on supply chain. Our goal is to increase the efficiency of back end hospital operations and their interface with nursing, with an outcome of nurses spending more time at the bedside with patients and improving patient outcomes and satisfaction.

Diligent Droids successfully deployed our mobile service robot with a partner hospital in Austin TX on three different dates in Nov/Dec 2016. This Phase I trial validated the feasibility of our core technology which center on: Autonomy and manipulation in human environments, and Social human-robot interaction.

Our healthcare service robots have the potential for positive societal impact by reducing the workload of staff whose primary responsibilities require special training and more human-centered skills, such as nurses. With U.S. life expectancy on the rise, skilled nurses are increasingly becoming more in demand. Automation could ameliorate the labor shortage by allowing humans to focus on providing more skilled care.  Diligent Droids aims for our technology to be general-purpose enough to transfer to other markets, such as long-term care facilities and eventually individual consumers. Robots that perform tasks in homes could increase the feasibility of independent living for many older adults.

During the SBIR Phase I the company demonstrated the prototype technology to our major hospital partners. These demonstration results culminated in a live demo and media event for the public on Dec. 20, 2016. Headlines of resulting stories in the media spoke to the potentially transformative impact of robot assistants on the future of hospital-based healthcare delivery - Assistant of the future; Seton Medical Center steps into future with robot assistant; Austin Nurses get Closer Look at Future Hospital Assistant. One outlet noted: “What will hospitals look like in the next generation? If they start following in the footsteps of Seton Medical Center in Austin, you may see more robots lending a helping hand, literally.”

One of the primary activities of this project has been the development of the core robotic technologies for our hospital service robot. The project focused on developing the mobility capabilities with social intelligence, which enables the robot to robustly navigate in a hospital around the staff. Another key technical thread has been developing the manipulation components of the platform, with a focus on manipulation in dynamic human environments. We now have a working prototype of our core IP, and have proved that our approach can successfully be deployed in a variety of hospital settings to enable a robot to quickly adapt to novel objects and environments without prior knowledge.

Academically, the primary impact of the technology of this project is in the field of Human-Robot Interaction (HRI). There are relatively few examples of real-world deployment of robot systems in dynamic human environments. Even less so of robots that have the ability to manipulate the environment with an arm and end effector. Our core technology is enabling a mobile manipulation robot to function on a real hospital unit, by quickly adapting its skill set during deployment. The HRI community can now see what is possible in achieving complex manipulation skills in a semi-structured environment. Additionally, the HRI community will continue to learn about hospitals as a target environment as Diligent Droids brings its product to market in the future.

The principal other discipline to be impacted by the results of this project is the field of Nursing. Nursing has not directly benefitted from advances in healthcare robotics, which have to date been limited to supply chain, pharmacy, and surgical procedures. The results of our observations suggest there are many opportunities for social robots to reduce the amount of time nurses on acute care units spend in non-value-added activities.

Diligent Droids is specifically working toward a collaborative solution where the robot takes on non-patient facing tasks, giving RNs more time for direct patient care. This helps hospitals achieve their goal of getting all staff to perform at the top of their license. Nearly 100,000 Americans are hospitalized each day, which adds up to nearly 40 million hospitalizations per year. The providers, in an effort to maintain cost competitiveness and quality outcomes, will need our hospital service robot technology solution.

The success of Diligent Droids’ Phase I project shows the feasibility of a hospital service robot that is autonomous, mobile, capable of manipulation, and is socially appropriate for working collaboratively in dynamic hospital environments.
